oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 'No More Shall the War Cry Sever' 75 Years Ago Today Fort Sanders Hill Ran Red With Blood of 392 Confederate Soldiers By JOHN S. VAN GILDER Especially Written For The Knoxville News-Sentinel of November 29, 1938. Early this morning, the milkmen, quietly placed their white bottles around West Knoxville in the vicinity of Fort Sanders Manor and Fort Sanders Hospital. Alarm clocks woke peacefully sleeping mothers, fathers and children. Hot breakfasts were comfortably eaten. Happy school boys and girls romped down the streets toward their schools. College boys hustled toward the Hill. Business men pressed the self-starters of their streamline automobiles, and wives sighed with relief, as husbands sped toward offices. Not so was this scene, 75 years ago, for today is the 75th anniversary of the famous Battle of Fort Sanders. Union soldiers within the earthen fort which stood near the present site of Fort Sanders Manor, were breathlessly awaiting, just as they had awaited throughout the long, unhappy night, the stealthy, silent approach, through the cold November fog, of attacking Confederate soldiers led by General Longstreet. And many of those attacking Confederate soldiers had wives and sweethearts and children in their captured Knoxville homes, separated from them by Knoxville's occupation by Union soldiers, under the command of General Burnside of "burnside whiskers" fame! Federal General Slain Slowly, during the Confederate siege of Knoxville, the aggressive Confederate soldiers had driven the retreating Union forces back up Kingston Pike toward Knoxville, the Union base. The Union Brigadier General William P. Sanders, a few days be- for the Battle of Fort Sanders, had been mortally wounded atop the hill now occupied by the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Briscoe, Jr., while sitting astride his beautiful white horse beside a green cedar tree. The accurate aim of a Confederate sharpshooter, hidden in a tree near the site of the present residence of Mr. and Mrs. Alex A. Bonnyman, had sent this famous Kentucky General to his doom. Through the freezing, misty morning air of November 29th, 1863, exactly 75 years ago today, the Confederate soldiers, at 4 o'clock on this Sunday morn, assaulted the western side of Fort Sanders. Ice was on the ground. Charging toward the Fort, the valiant Confederates tripped and fell on invisible wires which had been strung by Union soldiers amid tree stumps. Withering fire from Fort Sanders mowed the fallen Confederates down. Wildly cheering and with tattered Confederate banners flying, the Confederates reached the base of the Union breastworks, only to fall forward and plunge into an invisible trench dug around the base of Fort Sanders. The ice-glazed earthen works made a Confederate ascent of the Fort impossible. Union soldiers stood within the Fort and mowed down the entrapped Confederates with murderous cross fire. Exploding hand grenades, lighted by Union soldiers from their cigars, were tossed amid the helpless, bleeding, screaming Confederates caught in the deadly trench below the Fort. Blood in the trench was over shoe-top deep. The furious Battle of Fort Sanders lasted only 20 minutes. 392 Confederates Die As the mists rose on this battle scene, 75 years ago today, and the sun came peeping over the eastern mountains, the sun's rosy light fell on the marble-white faces of 392 Confederate soldiers, who lay in death on the bloody slopes of unconquerable Fort Sanders. They would never see their beloved wives, sweethearts and children again! Within the not-to-be-captured Fort Sanders, only eight Union soldiers lost their lives.
